TW.evidence: Many of the scholars, who raise a more critical view toward China, would choose not to visit China for their own safety, as the physical security is less protected in China. Also, Taiwanese people have to apply for the Mainland Travel to travel to China. And the Chinese authorities are likely to barricade the applications of those they dislike during the process without given a specific reason. In contrast, more Taiwanese scholars have confronted the situation of being openly denied visa to or being deported back from Hong Kong since 2013. After the Hong Kong National Security Laws came into effect in 2020, most of the outspoken academics against critical opinions on PRC refrain from traveling to China, Hong Kong, or Macau.

KR.evidence: In 2019, dozens of Korean and Chinese students glared at each other for over four hours in the first floor lobby of the College of Humanities at Hanyang University in Seongdong-gu, Seoul. It started around 1 p.m. when about 10 members of this school's 'Student Group for Promoting the Truth About Hong Kong' posted two posters expressing support for the Hong Kong protests. Five Chinese students passing by began protesting about this. They immediately rushed to remove the poster and engaged in a physical fight, bumping shoulders and pushing and pulling with the Korean students. Instead of taking off the poster, the Chinese students stuck notes on the poster with the five-star red flag (Chinese flag), 'Long live Kim Jong-un', and 'Dokdo is Japanese territory'. Still, the confrontation continued. The number of Chinese students increased over time, reaching about 40 at 5 p.m. The standoff ended when a security guard intervened.
KR.answerer: Answered by Muhammad Zulfikar Rakhmat, and has been reviewed by Yeta Purnama

GB.evidence:
There is no publicly available evidence of pressure against British academics since China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs sanctioned Dr Jo Smith Finley in 2021. Professor Steve Tsang, former head of the University of Nottingham School of Contemporary Chinese Studies (SCCS), said recently in a Channel 4 documentary that the SCCS was shut down in 2016 in response to pressure from Beijing. Tsang has openly criticised the CCP on several occasions and accused the university management of asking him not to speak to the media during Xi's visit to the UK in 2015. While this case is significant, it falls outside of the reporting period, justifying a 'No' response.

It must be said that the pressure exerted on academics cannot be reflected adequately by 'hard' evidence of coercion. The ambiguity of what is acceptable or not creates fear and confusion comparable to or more significant thatn any single high-profile case. The 'case' classification of evidence also makes it difficult to take into account the long-lasting impact of reported cases.
GB.answerer: Answered by Leo Shaw, and has been reviewed by Sam Dunning and Andrew Yeh
